captions.text:
I might not be here and
we wouldn't be looking at
this together, so...

Ruby Bridges:
Just having him say that meant
a lot to me and it always has.

But to be standing shoulder
to shoulder with history and

viewing history -- it's
just once in a lifetime.

The painting depicts my walk
into William Franz School,

integrating the public
school systems in 1960.

The President:
Can you still put your
head back into these times?

Ruby Bridges:
Oh, can I.
Absolutely.

The President:
Still -- you can still
kind of go back there?

Ruby Bridges:
Definitely; yes.
And I do.
Every day.

The girl in that painting at
six years old knew absolutely

nothing about racism -- I
was going to school that day.

But the lesson that I
took away that year,

in an empty school building, was
that none of us know anything

about disliking one another
when we come into the world.

It is something that
is passed on to us.

So every time I see that, I
think about the fact that I was

an innocent child that knew
absolutely nothing about what
was happening that day.

But then I learned a
very valuable lesson,

and that is, is that we should
never look at a person and judge
them by the color of their skin.

That's the lesson I
learned in first grade.

title: Ruby Bridges visits with the President and her portrait

comments.author: DeeRock

comments.text:
To see Obama trying to bask in the light of the ineffable bravery this 
woman demonstrated as a child, as if it reflects on him in any way, as if 
he somehow carries it forward by merely being the first president of color 
despite the clear contempt he's shown towards his constituents since day 
one through his actions and lack of action, is sickening. It sickens me in 
the same way his swearing in on MLK's bible sickens me.

The eminent scholar Cornel West put it best when he referred to Obama as a 
"Rockefeller Republican in blackface." Once the novelty of a biracial 
president who is an amazing rhetorician wears off, any mildly inquisitive 
person comes to see that his word means nothing. He is every ounce the 
warmonger that his predecessors were. He continued the absolute worst of 
the Bush doctrine and added his own flairs such as the NDAA. Executive 
shredding of our Constitution continues unabated. Indeed, Obama was the one 
who finally convinced me:  Democrat, Republican -- just two sides of the 
same corporate-controlled coin. And now a scientific study from Princeton 
proves it: the US is no longer a democracy, it is an oligarchy. And Obama 
is another one of those careerist, power-thirsty loyalists to corporate 
interests. Nothing more, nothing less.

I continue to despise the deeply ingrained racism that pervades those 
"conservative" elements of society who protested Obama before he even had a 
chance to have a seat in the Oval Office. But I GLADLY take up a place 
beside them calling for his ouster. He is just as culpable for his 
criminality as all the white men of the past few decades who preceded him.﻿

comments.text:
Ruby Bridges visited the White House to see how a painting commemorating 
her personal and historic milestone looks hanging on the wall outside of 
the Oval Office. American Artist Norman Rockwell was criticized by some 
when this painting first appeared on the cover of Look magazine on January 
14,1964; now the iconic portrait will be on display throughout the summer 
of 2011 in one of the most exalted locations in the country.﻿

comments.author: William Jones

comments.text:
When she was just six years old, Ruby Bridges became the first African 
American to integrate an elementary school in the south. She courageously 
walked into school flanked by four U.S. Marshals. The event was later 
depicted in a Norman Rockwell painting. To celebrate the 50th anniversary, 
it hung outside the Oval Office during summer 2011. Watch a video that 
shows her visit to meet President Obama and view the painting﻿

International Business Wales told me my work would never sell in the USA. 
And that is why the refused to invest. My fairy book is advertised on the

horrible black mould damp house because there is no justice. And I work in 
a run down school canteen with asbestos on the roof which has leaked three 
times. Adult sites trash my work on the Internet. Justice?

comments.text:
"I would rather be black than Jack" - this is why my friend is leaving

Wales trashed my work then went to kiss me on the lips.

grandchildren are blonde and fair haired she said. Nan lost both her 
parents at the age of four she cried for her Mother. She was put in a 
children's home because Granny could not get the money out of the English 
Government for her dead sons Army Pension. Nan and her brothers eat and 
slept in a shed which was called a children's home.I am white & suffer

comments.text:
@merrysmerrys Blacks in the South were "in harm's way" pretty much all the 
time even before the schools were officially desegregated. Many of them, as 
well as many whites, risked a lot in the fight for equal rights, & this 
event was part of that slow and not always steady progress towards making 
life better and safer for children like Ruby Bridges and for people of 
color in general. It's very naive to think Ruby's life would have been 
"safer" had events like this not happened.
comments.author: WildeNotesMusic

comments.text:
@magoo59 People on another YouTube video were commenting on Sidney Poitier 
and his historic Oscar win. One young person said..."I don't get it. Why is 
it such a big deal that he won?" He couldn't understand why a black person 
couldn't win. I explained, briefly, the atmosphere of the times. It made me 
realize that, although I don't believe in dredging up the past all the 
time, we really shouldn't forget the lessons of the past. Not slavery, not 
the Holocaust, etc. History is important.
comments.author: ohsnapitsme59

comments.text:
@merrysmerrys She wasn't 'put' into harms way. She was IN harms way simply 
because she wanted to go to school. I think this is one of the most 
powerful of Rockwell's paintings and I think it should be on display. It 
sends a powerful message to ALL people. And when you see some of the sick 
comments on this board (not yours), we can see how this message is still, 
unfortunately, needed.
comments.author: ohsnapitsme59

good to reflect on how far we have come and draw inspiration to continue. 
The one remaining thing Obama has going for him, as far as I'm concerned, 
is his skin. To the extent that he can inspire young people of color to 
excel, maybe some good will come of these years.
